clean_story:
"Crushed atoms. Gravity’s ultimate test. "

"Neutron star density limits" describe how tightly matter can pack before collapsing into a black hole.


A sugar-cube-sized piece of neutron star weighs as much as a mountain. This happens when a dying star’s core collapses, squeezing protons and electrons into neutrons—like crushing a soda can into a marble.

The limit is called the Tolman-Oppenheimer-Volkoff (TOV) boundary. If a neutron star grows beyond ~2. 2 solar masses, gravity wins, and it becomes a black hole. Think of it like stacking books: too many, and the shelf breaks.

Observations of PSR J0740+6620, a 2. 08-solar-mass neutron star, push this limit. Its density? 1 billion tons per teaspoon.

Three related subjects are quark stars, black hole formation, and quantum gravity’s unsolved puzzles.
